reviewText:
Currently, there are a large number of problems with the game. It is a direct PS4 port, which means the keyboard and mouse support is non-existent. If you want fluid gameplay on the PC, you'll need to find a way to use a console gamepad on the PC. The online game play has its own problems, monsters are out of sync with other players, more often than not you will see your allies swinging mindlessly at nothing. You will only experience this problem if you can even find an online lobby.

There is no communication options with other players besides pre-set messages that you have to scroll through a menu for. If you are lucky enough to have an enjoyable time experience this game in a random lobby with other players, there is no options to add fellow Slayers on Steam. In addition to this, the online game hub is very limited, it's a message board room where you can pick up missions, quests, and change equipment. If you want to do any sort of gear upgrade, you must leave the online lobby into single player mode to craft items. You risk losing your place with a possibly very good Slayer party.

There is no way of playing with friends on your Steam friends list, unless you live close enough to one another and you just happen to find the other person's lobby when searching online. I tested this with a friend of mine from Hong-Kong and it was not going to happen. We created games with passwords, and there was no way of finding or joining one another's lobbies.

There are, however, positives, not many, but they are there. The game is fun if you can get into a lobby with other fellow Slayers who know what they are doing and are competent. The 30 frame-rate cap is not as big of a problem as all people are making it out to be, the game is pretty, the 30 frames is very playable. The removal of the cap would be a huge improvement for the experience though.  The gameplay is nice and polished, no graphical glitches, no gameplay glitches thus far.

For $60, and the immensely poor optimization, the game is not worth your money. Save your money until the game is patches and fixes these basic issues. Considering that it is not playable as a PC port, I will not recommend this game to anyone as of yet.

I will recommend this game to the die hard fans out there looking for a Monster Hunter equivalent on PC. If you have a console game controller and know how to use it with your PC, definitely give it a go, the game is fully playable with a console controller. If you have any questions about the actual gameplay or would like to see the game play, feel free to drop by my twitch stream at www.twitch.tv/ricecraker . Hope this review was helpful, and happy hunting!

I get some people are having problems getting this game to run and I know it had some issues on launch but this happens with so many PC games.
Koei sorted out what was needed yet they still get ripped hard in the forums and through reviews its unneeded and misdirected.
This game is great its a monster hunter for pc but with Koei's touch.

Pros -
- Controls with a Xbox remote are tight and responsive.
- Gameplay is addictive, slay a monster or monsters level up your weapons, amour then back out for a new hunt.
- A nice amount of amour and weapons to pick from and the attention to detail with this stuff makes every piece completely different.
- Can change the way you play by picking a new weapon set.
- Graphics are nice its just your standard Koei look but if you turn your TV brightness down makes everything seem more intense.
- Story is spot on not to weak and not in your face a nice way to break up to constant war with the oni.
- Multiplayer I haven't scoped out but im sure its all sweet.
- The music is nice it hasent become repetitive, you end up so focused on the mission at hand you only really have time to appreciate it once your back in the village.
- So many missions.

Cons-
- Should have split screen, I feel this really wouldn't of been hard to whack in.
- No difficulty, wish there was more of a reason to re-do old hunts other than for fun.  Its in most of there games would have really enjoyed cranking mission 1 on intense difficulty and feeling that pressure.

Overall, I doubt this game would be worth the full price, even if it ran properly on PC. I wouldn't recommend it until the technical problems are fixed and the game goes on sale.

reviewText:
A great game that stands tall with other games of its kind. The whole game is set in a version of feudal Japan whose timeline has been distorted and land twisted up by the Oni, the demons of Japanese folklore. Though many will call Toukiden a Monster Hunter *clone*, it feels more apt to call it a Monster Hunting *game*. It's very different from Monster Hunter and in a good way.

https://youtu.be/TzRZMP3w8y0

+ Mitamas = Spirits of historical figures of feudal Japan. Load them into your weapons. Get stat boosts/special abiulities. Using Mitamas to create your own unique loadout is gratifying. Bonuses for using Mitamas historically related to one another. Incentive to play around with different combinations. TONS of bonus effects.

+ Gathering items to create consumables has been replaced by stock powers that do the same things as Potions, Antidotes, Cool Drinks, etc. and then some! Your abilities change depending on the type of Mitama you have equipped. Less prep work, more demon fighting.

+ Great weapon choices and fighting styles. Each weapon plays a little differently than the other. Skill plays a moderate factor in the combat; the better you know how to use your weapon, the better slayer you are.

- (I'm coming off of MH4U's almost-G-Rank HR stuff) Monster AI is a little too dumb in the beginning, and by the beginning I mean SEVERAL hours. Probably only highlighted by the fact that teammate AI in the single player campaign is VERY good. Monster AI does get smarter at a much faster rate than the teammate AI, so it balances out, but be prepared for some lazy demons early on.

- The PC Port comes at a rocky recommendation as the multiplayer apparently has issues, but if you're still interested in a strong solo Monster Hunting experience this is definitely something you should give a go.

reviewText:
Toukiden: Kiwami is an action-RPG.
The protagonist is a new Slayer in the Utakata village, located at the border of Oni(demon)-free world. The one and only task is to protect humans (and Tenko) from Oni.
Character's appearance and starting weapon are customizable. New weapon and armor can be purchased from merchants or crafted from Oni parts. Mitama (spirits of historical figures or fictional characters) determine character's class and abilities. Mitama can be obtained from defeated Oni only.
The process of slaying a large Oni starts with destroying its body parts (legs, tails, etc.), then purifying those parts (otherwise the Oni regenerates it) then attacking the Oni true form (transparent, blue or purple). Oni's behavior changes during battle.
AI companions are adequate and helpful. Chapters and Phases are similar, but the former is Offline Story mode, while the latter is Online mode.
Graphics, sound (warning, there's no English VA) and controls (customizable key bindings) are fine.

reviewText:
If you've ever played a Monster Hunter game than you've got an idea of what to expect here. Toukiden: Kiwami takes a few
notes from the format of Monster Hunter and improves upon them. You've got access to a great amount of weapons that are
all very interesting in thier own ways, which is where Toukiden shines. At this game's core, it is an action RPG with
more focus on the action part.

When you drop yourself into a mission, you're able to move freely, loot items you find and either engage or dodge enemies
as you choose. More often than not you're going to be after a specific enemy or set of enemies, so you'll be fighting
something. Just as expected, with any Monster Hunter experience, you will be put up against large scale monsters that are
very dangerous. This is the meat and potatoes of the game.

Every large monster has body parts that can be removed and mechanic changes that occur as you remove more and more limbs.
As you remove limbs you also loot (or purify as this game calls it) said body parts. You also gain parts as rewards for
killing the monsters, removing some limbs or all limbs as quest rewards. You take these body parts and use them to craft
new weapons and armor to further expand your access to elements that can help you take on monsters with greater ease, or
in new interesting ways.

As stated before, as you purify removed limbs there are ghost limbs that become visible. These are how you actually defeat
large scale monsters. You have to remove the limbs, purify them and then gain access to the actual lifebar of the boss.
On a basic level the removal of limbs is basically just like breaking off armor exposing the true body.

Once you begin crafting, you'll see with time that there are tons of items to make and collect. You will end up finding
youself wanting to craft everything but never having the resorces to do it, creating an excitement every time you get
something new and driving you to keep playing.

Souls of fallen warriors will be items you will come across in the game that give you more interesting ways to customize
your character's loadout. With each soul comes a set of abilities that really change the way you play be it giving you
more stamina, a shield allowing you to wail away at an enemy or buffs to help out your whole party.

There is a story mode that provides a story interesting enough to keep you going with purpose, but not enough to really
come running to your friends wanting to talk about. It's just enough, but nothing special.

Toukiden does have a level of difficulty present, but if you use the in-game AI assistants you're going to ruin your
experience if you're interested in challenge. The AI totally breaks the game and makes it so easy you really don't even
need to play. The AI will do everything for you. The AI seem a little too powerful for thier own good too. As they should
have just been there as minor assistance and destraction, they do so much more with thier overpowered gear.

::Pros::
-Very interesting weapon mechanics
-Weapons are very different allowing you to play in different styles to keep the game fresh
-solo difficulty is really fun
-online mode accessable for co-op fun with friends
-tons of equipment to collect (for completionists)
-Souls create more depth in creating a fun and unique way to play each time

::Cons::
-AI is way too good
-AI use makes game way too easy
-a little slow at first
-game searching is a little inconvenient
-online lobby is odd and limits your ability to craft

Games like Toukiden are designed in a way that speak to a more specific crowd. If you like collecting items and like
games that can be grindy at times, Toukiden may be a great addition to your library. I would say that fans of action
games in general could probably get into and appreciate this game as well. If you're a player who likes things to always
be fresh and not recycled like playing in the same zones or fighting the same enemies over and over again, than this
game will not be for you. A warning to fans of Monster Hunter would be that this game is far far more forgiving and
contants a diffculty/skill curve that isn't quite so extreme, but the game makes up for it other ways. If the difficulty
of Monster Hunter is what you play for then you may be at risk buying this game, so I would suggest getting it on sale.

Ahh good ol' port 'problems'.
Keyboard controls and keybinding
For those of you familliar with rebinding keys in the days of PPSSPP/PCSX2 and/or playing ports like DMC3SE on PC with just a keyboard, rest assured - you'll feel right at home with this game.

For those unwilling to re-map their brains to memorize that left shift is L1 and spacebar is R1 and so on, for your own sanity, stay away. Stay FAR away from ANY game that was ported from a non-PC platform to PC. Also, stay away the ported game's guides/walkthroughs/tutorials, because they're all gonna probably be referencing the controller keys instead of the keyboard keys too.

CAPCOM did it this way with DMC3SE LONG ago and nobody complained - in fact, back in those days many of the crazy-fast combo maniacs that you often see in youtube dmc3 videos used keyboards and not controllers of any sort, simply because it was relatively easier to jump cancel in quick succession with a keyboard than with a controller.

Seriously, I don't see what the big deal is that could come from just taking 10 minutes to learn to set-up keyboard controls to mimic a controller, and THEN learning to memorize your own keyboard setup. All this 'controls learning' is a moot point if you already own an xbox/ps controller though.

All that being said, I do NOT recommend you start playing WITHOUT first rebinding the keys to something that feels natural for you relative to a controller layout (I rebound only 4 keys in total to feel like old dmc3 controls, and also having Q,E,F,R as default camera controls is just a bonus in my opinion, because in DMC3 I don't recall being able to rebind camera controls away from the arrow keys).

Mouse support?
Oh and before I forget, those of you complaining about the lack of mouse controls - where would you put the 4 attack/dodge functions tied to the keys for your right hand onto the mouse?

Sure, you could put dodge somewhere on the left hand (say.. Z key) and then you're left with the 3 attack functions - just nice for 3 mouse keys/clicks right? Wrong.

As a naginata/gauntlet user you end up having to spam your middle mouse button for your Special Attacks(circle key on PS4) - I'd instantly switch back to the keyboard just because of this.

Yes, games like Vindictus did it, but they didn't have a 3rd attack key. There were only L and R combos (left click and right click).

Indie game devs like the Japanese folks at Zenith Blue had the right idea - look at their Mitsurugi Kamui Hikae game.

In summary, lack of mouse functionality is less a technical 'problem' and more of a game design constraint:

Would you rather have 2 attack buttons (with combo variations limited by 2 keys) and precise camera controls with a mouse? (i.e. like Vindictus)

OR would you rather have 3 (or more) attack buttons (with a LOT more combo variations/combat scenarios) on the keyboard and 4 keys controlling camera movement (with adjustable speed)?

If you prefer stuff like Vindictus, then play Vindictus.. or wait for games like Black Desert Online.

Please note that Toukiden Kiwami on PC has a hard framerate cap of 30 frames per second; hardcoded framerate == if you were to increase it, you end up hastening the game's physics cycles (i.e. time itself goes faster).

My opinion on the framerate cap is this - I can see it, I know it's bad/ugly, but I don't care; the game still responds quickly to my input regardless of the FPS cap and I'm able to time my dodges and parries with the same accuracy as what games like DMC4SE and DMC3SE has allowed me (look up DMC royal guard just guards and just releases, this is what you will do with the naginata and hammer counter-attack in Toukiden Kiwami - hint: that's your square+x attack).

In short, the game is framerate capped, but still responds instantly to your input regardless. If it doesn't your PC probably isn't beast enough to play this stuff.

I have been a Monster Hunter fan since I first played it on the PS2 years ago. I'm primarily a PC gamer and always wanted a PC port of MH, but that never happened. When I found this game, I was very excited. I have enjoyed the game so far, but it does have some technical problems and the game is very shallow when compared to MH.

The technical problems I have had with it are extremely low frame rates anywhere outside of the mission areas. I have experienced some minor freezing (a couple of seconds now and then) inside missions, but for the most part, the missions have been playable without much of a problem. I see a lot of people complaining about the poor keyboard/mouse support, but I use a controller so I have nothing to add to those complaints. It works just fine with a controller.

All voice acting is in Japanese, but the text is all English (assuming you want English) and while it might be nice to hear the voice acting in English, it doesn't cause any issues with playability for English speaking gamers. If you can tolerate the low frame rates in town (and even that isn't a constant problem, but happens often) and plan on using a controller, then I think you'll find little else in the way of technical problems to prevent you from enjoying the game. If you've played MH a lot and enjoyed it, you may find this is a pale comparison, but otherwise, it's not a bad game, just not a great one. The price does seem very steep ($60 USD) and I expect it may come down before long.

I'd give this game a 3 out of 5 in its current state. I know the developers are still working on improvements and patches seem to be happening on a regular basis so that's a good thing.

tl;dr version: A good game unfortunately marred by shoddy work in the porting. Locked at 30fps, if you care about that sort of thing, and very hit and miss at the moment. Some will be able to run this no problem, and some may have problems running it with certain Nvidia cards, and some may not even be able to run it at all.

The game itself plays like a Monster Hunter type, with several weapon types with their own movesets and gimmicks, and passive skills attained not from armor, but from souls one can equip and level to unlock more passive skills. Each soul are categorized into different types, such as Attack, Speed, Defense and the likes, with each of those types having three active skills unique to the type.

The combat are fast paced, though early on in the chapters the enemies are sluggish, weak and tend to stand around doing their idle animation. Then in the later chapters, it slaps you in the gonads, kick your dog, and burns your pancakes, as monsters get faster and gain new attacks.

The AI companions you can choose to bring along to both offlne and online are thankfully intelligent, as far as I could see from my own games, so they rarely need to be babysitted, and very often able to take care of themselves.

The Graphics are good, though locked at 30 fps, if youre the type to care about those. For me, 30 fps still looks smooth on my computer, so I didn't mind.

All in all, it plays like Monster hunter, with much less emphasis of the preparation and gathering, and more into the combat and action. Gathering is still important though.

reviewText:
This game has been receiving some bad reviews calling it a horrible port. I am writing my first ever steam review to say it is fact a great, very fun game.  Also TLDR version at very bottom.

Negatives (Not really)

I only truly see two “issues” with this game really. The lack of mouse/keyboard, and the 30 FPS lock. The 30 FPS lock is not an issue to me as this game runs VERY smooth for me. I have had no stutters, glitches, or crashes in my 15 hours of play. Granted I have a EVGA Windforce GTX 770 4gb card, but I am playing with every setting maxed, and I feel lesser hardware should run this fine. The mouse/keyboard may been a huge problem for some people. This game is designed for a controller, and ported with one in mind, plain and simple. There are no keyboard buttons on screen, and even using a keyboard and mouse everything on screen still refers to X,Y,A,B keys. Koei has a problem with doing this on their latest ports as Dynasty Warriors 8: Empire did the same, but in reverse as it only showed keyboard commands in game. As I only use controllers for these types of game, that game did bother the HELL out of me, so I can see the keyboard/mouse community's issues here.

Positives

This is a Monster Hunter style game on pc, plain and simple if you are into that sort of thing. There a quite a few different maps to run around, varied monsters, and crafting to make bigger better weapons to slay with. The game is faster paced than Monster Hunter, but is still slower than Dynasty Warriors. Add to this a pseudo spell system and different weapon types and styles; you end up with a surprisingly deep game once you start trying out different weapons and skill builds.

The story is pretty good. Nothing super deep or profound, but it does give you a reason to kill all those demons, and I genuinely find myself liking many of the characters as you get to interact with them and learn their back stories.

Online – There is up to 4 player co-op through the games missions, and I can say it is hella fun (if you can find other people to play with). Some folks say their game had horrible online syncing, well as far as I can tell there is no server based gameplay. If the host has crap internet then you will experience lag. I hosted my own online matches, and had no issues with the other players syncing. If you want to minimize the potential for lag go into the settings and tell it to only connect to other English players. I have never seen a Japan hosted game ever run smoothly.

TLDR

If you want a fun Monster Hunter style game on pc, this game is great; as long as you don’t mind using a controller. It wont ever receive the glorious pc master race seal of approval for its port job, but as long as you aren’t “trying to run it on a potato” (a quote from my best friend) you should have a great experience with many hours of play ahead of you.

reviewText:
EDITED: SEE BELOW

At this time, I can't recommend this game to anybody. I also own this game on PS4 and there it works very well, i've almost completed the story and I have dozens of hours sank into it. I was worried what with this being a port and the track record the company has concerning ports, but I took a gamble and bought it anyway. Luckily I have two weeks to get a refund, so i'm waiting for any information to be released shortly before that deadline concerning any patches they have in mind to solve this port's many issues before I submit my request for a refund.  On console the game's great.

The two most glaring problems at the moment in my personal experience make the game unplayable.

The first is that when I run this game in fullscreen, it will either freeze at a black screen permanently or crash. Fun!

Second, if I used windowed to work around this problem then the game performs terribly. The framerate is nowhere near static; I doubt it's ''locked'' to 30, 30 is probably just the best it can do, if you have the seemingly random requirements and specs it takes to have this actually work at all.  The tutorial fight and first visit to town that followed was like I was playing the game in slow motion. It was slow and choppy.

As for a final statement, avoid this game. It's ridiculous that this company can just keep tossing out poor quality ports and not keep anyone updated on if they plan to rectify their mistakes. I may change this review at a later date if they put the work in to fix this, but if not, then it's just another tally on the list of bad ports from the company. It's honestly a fantastic game if it would actually work.

EDIT: By running the game as administrator in compatibility mode with windows 7, I was able to rid myself of most of the problems presented. Now that I can give an actual review of the game (sans the online component, haven't tried that out yet) I can explain some things.

Story: The story of this game is stronger than the counterpart series, or at least from what i've played of it, meaning Monster Hunter. You play the part of a created Slayer, a militarized demon slaying individual that has the ability to speak with and work with the souls of legendary heroes who grant you abilities, called Mitama. There are NPC characters with their own personal storylines to follow, though most of their personalities are somewhat trope-ish. It has more in the story department than most Monster Hunter games, but it's nothing groundbreaking; be a big hero, you're a unique snowflake, yadda yadda and so on.

Gameplay: I like to think of the gameplay as a cross between Monster Hunter and Dynasty Warriors. Combat as a whole is more fast paced and aggressive. Weapons swing faster than in Monster Hunter, combos are in general longer and easier to perform, and the Demons in this game are more aggressive and more durable than most I remember fighting in MH3U or MH4U. You kill demons for materials, use said materials to craft gear, and kill bigger demons. It's a hunting game. There is also a teamwork component. One side of this mechanic is that if you go down, you don't immediately ''cart''. You go into a bleedout and allies can help you up, but if the demon is angry enough sometimes this isn't very possible to perform. On the other side, there's Team Destroyer moves. Each weapon type's Team Destroyer is different in animation, but generally just deals huge damage.

Before I go any further with that, the combat in Toukiden revolves around you dismembering large demons, cutting limbs off of their physical bodies to reveal a ''spirit body'' underneath it. You can purify physical limbs, which works a lot like carving, and prevents the demon from regenerating that limb. Hitting the spirit body is what does actual damage to the demon. Back to Team Destroyers. Basically, as you fight, you have a normal Destroyer gauge, which is a one man super move that instantly hacks off a limb and does high damage, and the Team Destroyer gauge fuels a move that when the gauge is filled allows you to approach allies and connect to them with lines of electricity. The more connections you have, the more limbs you sever with a team Destroyer if your aim is good enough.

Speaking of weapons, there's something for everyone.There's the melee category, with the Sword, Spear, Knives, Chain Sickle, Naginata, Fists, and Hammer, and the ranged category with Bows and Guns. Each one obviously has its own moveset and and specialties, so there's pretty much something for everybody.

Graphics:

Sound: The music I feel is fairly well done and fits with the mood of what you're doing at the moment. The town theme is peaceful and calm, while when in the field the music will switch between standard battle music and more intense music when fighting a large demon. The sound effects for the most part are done well, with each hit you deliver, take, or evade having an appropriate level of volume. You hear your feet hit the ground when you sprint, you hear impact noises when landing hits with your weapon, and standard stuff along those lines. The music of the game fits the mood and setting well.

Controls: Unfortunately this is one of the areas the game falls short. If you don't have a controller, I would suggest holding off on buying this title until you do. The keyboard controls are godawful and from what I understand can't be remapped. I use an Xbox 360 controller, though, and I didn't struggle with any controls. Everything was pretty much exactly where I had expected it to be upon plug in. Being a hunting game, the controls are very responsive and there's almost never a moment where you'll take a hit you feel like shouldn't have connected.

Replay: Being a hunting game, replay value is up in the air. You have three characters slots, but if you really wanted to, you could build every weapon and armor set in the game along with all Mitama on one character. It'd be a grind, but it's totally doable. With that, replay would be a pretty optional thing here. Being it's the only game of its type currently on steam that I know of, i'll likely do several runs through it myself.

Final: If you'd like a hunting game on PC, check this out if you have a controller. I can't guarantee the solution I found will work for everyone, but assuming it does, this is a good game in its own right that sets itself apart from being a clone of Monster Hunter. It has its own pacing and flow, not to mention its own features and quirks that make it fun all on its own.

reviewText:
I'm going to make no comparisons and just focus on what I found worked and did not work in this game.

What worked,

Combat: feels fluid and the weapon types range simple (longswords) to exotic (sickle and chain). AI teammates help out a lot in combat with breaking parts, purifying them, and healing you if you fall. However, combat is quite easy and once you know a good combo, that's what you will use in every battle essentially. However, skills are a changable way to add flavor to the slashing and hacking.

Gathering: there is not a lot of grinding required to get certain materials and once you attain a certain helper, it becomes extremely easy to get non monster materials, and there do not seem to be extreely rare monster materials so it only ends up taking a 1 or 2 kills to get what you want.

Upgrading: Upgrading equipment happens after a boss kill and you will really only have to re-kill that boss abut 5 times to get a full set of equipment, and then there is fortifying which you can do after using certain equipment for a certain amount of time, for no material or monetary cost.

What doesn't work

Missions: While I personally prefer it, the missions are sort of arena style. There are different maps but only a few areas of said map available in each mission and monsters can't move areas. I understand this might be boring for many people, but I think it keeps the game action focused.

Story: The story is fairly run-of-the-mill save the world from impending doom. I am only in chapter 3 of 13 or something like that, and it is hinting at something more intricate, but I'm not sure if it will end up that way.

Finally, some comparisons (sorry). It is essentially an action alll the time monster hunter (no mining, gathering herbs, combining, no changing health bar or stamina bar size, no hunger) with the setting of something close to the manga/anime Bleach (sould devouring oni, souls in weapons, purifying souls) and I think this marriage goes exteremely well and that the way the game progresses lack a lot of the false difficulty that plagues the Monster hunter series (enemies run away, parts are super rare, slow animations, mining and pickaxe breaks randomly etc.). reviewText:
To start out, I'm a massive Monster Hunter fan and even though I hate to compare games I can't help myself sometimes so I'm going to weigh the pros and cons of this game here for you all. As a preface, most of the negative reviews under 30 minutes of gameplay are complete ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. I've played 15 hours in the game and haven't had a single crash or gameplay glitch, the 30 FPS lock is unnoticable and the game runs extremely smooth and looks beautiful, with that out of the way, here are my opinions.

Pros:
Fast, fluid combat.
Easy to access multiplayer.
Skills are easy to use and the Mitama system makes changing armor sets easy (especially compared to MH)
The Tenko companion is adorable and not annoying compared to the Palicoes in MH4U.
Graphically impressive.

Cons:
Forced to use a controller (I'm okay with it personally since all Koei Tecmo games on Steam pretty much require a controller)
Fights are easy to hack and slash (This one is mainly due to the Mitama I use, I'm able to get soak a free hit, and at the current stage I'm at, getting hit really doesn't do too much damage, that will most likely change in the future, till then it's a con)
Multiplayer lobby is one room only and lacking access to crafting, Tenko, and other village options. You're able to fortify your weapons/armor (which is a small stat boost to them) in the Lobby, but you can't see what you need to craft the next set, check what you Tenko brought you, or anything else village related without leaving the lobby entirely. This is okay if you have a dedicated friend to play with, but don't be surprised if you find it hard to keep playing with the same people as you keep leaving to check on your Tenko or see what that last boss's parts can be crafted into.

All in all, I highly recommend this game to anyone with a Controller and who's a fan of Monster Hunter style games. It's far more action based than Monster Hunter, there is no weapon sharpness, gather quests, potion maintenance or anything of the sort. It's purely hunting, and that's enjoyable to me. The cons are mainly my personal opinion of the game mechanics, and nothing actually game breaking.

WARNING: Game requires a little effort on the players side to play the game... This game is not spoon fed to you. This game requires skill, timing, and hand eye coordination....

Sorry to break it to you guys but this game is heavily skill based... sure no mouse support... so what? keyboard controls are intuitive and relatively easy to use. They are in clusters that do not feel out of the way from one of the other keys you are using. That being said I'm using qwerty.

Pro's:
-Smooth playing experience
-Graphics feel like the old monster hunter games (I like them but I guess it is preference)
-Unique enemies with different move sets that FEEL exciting when fighting a new archtype.
-AI allies are GREAT sometimes too good actually, often find myself only selecting two or three versus the four.
-Tons of item trees and enough elemental strengths / weaknesses for you to really put thought into what you'll face.
-Town buff system(s) keep you going back for the extra boost that may make or break your next run!
-A bunch of different weapon archtypes that allow for you to find a playstyle that fits you!

Cons:
-A little unusual setup required with some hardware
-Fiddling with settings often required for a good experience
-Leaves you wishing the team that ported this simply added the keyboard keys for the animation and button listings in game as you have to think for the first hour or so what x,y,a,b or start for instance translates to on the keyboard.

Now with that out of the way, after the initial setup my experience has been AMAZING with this game. I love this type of game so my opinion might be biased but I highly recommend this for anyone who loves monster hunter games. Yes this game is locked at 30 FPS, and? it runs and plays better than some AAA games have on launch. No there is no mouse support, would honestly make the game too easy. The complaints on the controls are unjustified, if you can't be bothered to learn the controls how do you think you'll do with the more advanced mechanics of the game? Controller support is there but for brand name controllers which I think is understandable but a bit lacking for a broader audience. All in all I don't see what most of the quips are about, I paid ~50$ for the game and would pay it again.

*settings that worked for me*
For those having issues running the game check particle setting as I had to set that to low in order to prevent my game from crashing with GTX 780 and run in compatability mode Windows 8... odd but its the settings that worked for me. Game now runs without any hiccups!

reviewText:
Where to start..
First of all: Toukiden is a one-of-a-kind hunting experience on the PC, in a unique mix between the button-mashing, spectacle fighting experience of Dynasty Warriors and Monster Hunter.
Sounds quite hard to manage, doesn't it? However Toukiden manages!
Hundreds of Armor und Weapon Sets each coming with it's own Stat-Boni and absolute gorgeous and unique design with each and every single Set. You have every possible customization option avaiable, up until the higher ranks.

What makes Toukiden different however is first and foremost it's Mitama System. Every few bosses/quests, you will loot a Mitama - some sort of Spirit Essence of Ancient Personalities (= that actually existed. It's really interesting to read up on those)
These Mitama can be inserted in your Weapons to give not only Stat Boni, but also alter your Skill Set. This highly influences the Dinamic of High-Ranked fights, when in a party of up to 4 players. It's way more engaging than Monster Hunter and communicating with your fellow Slayers is not only a necessity, but through a 5-Pages Message Menu not only easy but it can wholly substitute a voice chat, making Matchmaking with Strangers more pleasant than other Games of a similar genre.

Another huge difference is the much more developed story of Toukiden in contrast to Monster Hunter, a Story which albeit lacks depth, can be engaging in certain key moments and had me on the edge of my chair in certain situations, like the finale of Ch. 2. It manages your tension and keeps you interested, even if you may or may not be a fan of the hunting genre.

Lastly the Boss-Fights. They are exactly what you'd expect. It's Monster Hunter, but with giant, greatly designed Demons, based on Japanese Mythology. It has it's own charme, but I do find some of the Bosses lacking in personality in contrast to the Monster Hunter Franchise.


To conclude:
Toukiden is a gorgeous mix between Dynasty Warriors and Monster Hunter, which exceeds the Customization Options of the latter with the Mitama System. It tries to get you interested in the History surrounding this very over-the-top hunting game through the Mitama-History Section as well as reading up on what the Oni for example are actually based on.
The combat is fluent and keeps you hooked for hours on end, as well as being less grindy than Monster Hunter. Especially if you're shooting for a 100% Completion. Multiplayer got much more love and interaction between players is highly supported, which makes the random-matchmaking an absolute bliss.
Additionally (even if I lack some experience in that field) - the Game seems to have a very good Netcode, so that I was able despite my very bad Internet-Connection to even Host entire Lobbys without Lag or similar issues.

All in all, if you can be interested in the Style of Toukiden and you're looking for a more fast-paced Monster Hunter: This game is definitly woth every cent!

The port is barebones (30fps lock, game wasn't designed to run at more than 30 fps, so unlocking fps makes the game run really fast) but serviceable. I didn't get any crashes or weird stuff so far.
It's a ps4 port, not a Vita one (some people were saying that this is a Vita port, that's why I'm clarifying that)

VERY IMPORTANT: If you don't want to use a gamepad, forget about this game. There is no mouse support, and keyboard only controls can be really frustrating.

The voices are in Japanese, story is as one would expect from a monster hunting game. The gameplay is faster and easier than Monster Hunter, but can get interesting. There's online coop, and you can play solo if you want (the AI companions are pretty good)

All in all, I'd say that if you see a copy of this game going for 30-40 bucks and you like the Monster Hunter games, get it. For 60 dollars it's a tougher sell, but Tecmo Koei never knows how to price their games on PC, so that's what we got.

reviewText:
To rule out crashing issues and low FPS, see the bottom of my review.

Despite the hostility towards this game in other reviews, I decided to give it a shot and see how it went. I won't lie, so far I'm quite impressed. There are issues in the current state of the game, however I trust that these will be fixed, judging by the fact that the developers have already address and fixed some crashing issues.

Pros:
Gameplay is lots of fun
Voice acting is fantastic
Translation is great
Very well rendered cutscenes/cinematics
Lots of playtime
Very diverse and flexible playstyle to suit anyone
Cons:
30fps lock, however is not very noticeable when playing and does not cause input lag
Glitches where particles, effects and lighting is not rendered properly (does not affect gameplay)
Still some crashing issues and compatibility issues with Windows 8.1 (however fixable)
Appears to be some issues with keyboard/mouse, however I'm using an Xbox 360 controller
In the current state of the game, it is playable by all means, as long as you do the following:

Set all graphics settings to lowest

Now for all you people complaining about bugs, awful controls, and other stuff, the only problem I've had with this game is random crashing, which I'm sure they can fix soon enough. It also seems running in compatibility mode helps out with this. People complain about no use of mouse, but Dynasty Warriors was the same way. It just takes getting used to. My controller wouldn't even work for Dynasty Warriors but I just kept using the keyboard and I don't even care anymore. If you're that stuck up about it, go buy yourself a controller (Xbox 360 probably). It's a surprise you already don't have one if you play tons of different games on PC. Can't afford one? Not my problem, not Toei's problem. I've heard there's an issue with not being able to setup your own keybindings, and for that, I have nothing against since I myself had to change some key binding to play Dynasty Warriors on the keyboard.

Oh, and the last thing. Locked at 30 FPS? Who cares

So basically, this game is great, the only problem which is completely fixable is the random crashes. No need to whine about problems you could easily work around or that don't even matter

Bugs, Fixed and Edited
----------------------------------

- Now they lock game's frame at 30fps.

- After Updated to win10 crash still occurs.

---------------
I just tried this out and let game runs for a few hours so far it hasn't crash yet.

What I did is
+ After win10 upgraded I noticed my ToukidenKiwamiLauncher menu tab layout is massed up.
I didn't bother to check it properly up until now. [all tab name are hidden until your cursor over it]
+ A new tab have been added next to Graphic setting" called "Special Setting"
+ There is an option called "Stablization" inside this tab

- I switched this option "ON"
- I change my monitor refresh rate from 144 to 60 while playing this game.
- Also close G-sync and nvidia fps counter.

These seem to aid my problem. Anyone who have Crashing issue pls try this out."

The game isnt compatible with windows 8.1, which forces you to go to the files and change the compatibility to windows 7. The particles, doesnt matter wether you have a GTX 980 or An AMD card, will crash your game if you dont have them on low. The game its self, looks like it was ported from the vita, not the PS4.

All around, it saddens me that a game with SO much potential has such a small playing community because koei tecmo screwed us over with another awful port.
